Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Patrick Ryan Thomas of the University of Missouri, Kansas City (UMKC) to conduct a research project in physics during the summer of 2013 at the Department of Chemistry, School of Science and Technology, Kwansei Gakuin University in Japan. The project title is "Using Relativity in Calculations of the Optical and Electronic Properties of Materials." The host scientist is Professor Kazuyoshi Ogasawara.

This research consists of two specific objectives to improve the representation of the wave function within the orthogonalized linear combination of atomic orbitals (OLCAO) method for technologically important materials, in this case Cerium doped YAG laser crystals.
The first goal is to include relativistic effects in the wave function. Such relativistic orbitals are necessary but not sufficient for accurately computing key material properties such as the total energy and eliminating excessive errors which result in present calculations. The second objective is to develop an accurate approach to calculate the relativistic kinetic energy contribution by making use of a linear combination of kinetic energy calculations for isolated atoms.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture, and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. In addition to working with his host researcher, the Fellow is also visiting the research labs of two other Japanese scientists to explore prospects for future collaborations. Results will be made available to the larger physics community via technical conference presentations and publications. The cultural experiences will be shared through the UMKC physics department's web site and other media outlets. Additionally, the Fellow has regular direct interactions with area high school students and undergraduate science students as tutor and teaching assistant thus giving him the opportunity to share with students, including many from underrepresented groups, the study of physics in an international setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Inherent to the study of condensed matter physics is the desire to accurately predict and understand the fundamental properties of interesting materials. The materials studied can have applications across all fields of science from laser crystals to semiconductors. During the EAPSI fellowship, research was completed in how to better model materials containing elements with a large number of protons. The large number of protons in the nucleus of some elements causes the atom’s core electrons to accelerate to near the speed of light which in turn causes a variety of interesting phenomena regarding the electronic and optical properties of the material.

In years past, Professor Kazuyoshi Ogasawara of Kwansei Gakuin University (KGU) and Professor Rulis of the University of Missouri – Kansas City (UMKC) decided to merge together their computation methods – Discrete Variational Multi-Electron (DVME) and Orthogonalized Linear Combination of Atomic Orbitals (OLCAO) methods respectively. The resulting program would make use of the best features from each program and be incredibly effective at calculating the excited state properties of large systems containing dopant atoms in the structure. The task of merging the two software packages has numerous subtasks such as changing the analytical representation of the atomic orbitals to include relativistic effects, creating new atomic orbital interaction formulas to handle a more explicit description of the electron-electron interactions, and the inclusion of the effects of the relativistic electrons that the new atomic orbital representations enable.

This EAPSI fellowship and one conducted by a colleague in the previous year have been part of a continuing effort to tackle some of the subtasks necessary for the merger. My specific tasks were to first create an advanced fully relativistic representation of the electrons in the atoms that included all of the components necessary for a complete description of the relativistic effects and then to reduce this representation to a more simple form that would include only the so-called scalar relativistic effects such that it could be used immediately within the OLCAO program without excessive modification of the program. This would allow for direct testing of the development work associated with the second task. The second task involved collaborating directly with my host, Professor Ogasawara, to adapt a computational algorithm used for calculating the electronic kinetic energy of these materials. We had to first understand the quantum theory used in the formalism and then set about how to perform such a calculation with the electron descriptions present in OLCAO. Both of these tasks are pivotal for the merger of the programs.

In addition to the primary scientific benefits of the fellowship, I was overwhelming enriched professionally and personally by my experiences in Japan. The research constitutes the bulk of the work for my Master’s thesis and will serve as a springboard for hopeful future research in quantum field theory. At each institution, I was able to meet and associated with talented scientists and great people. During the orientation session at Sokendai, I was able to spend a weekend with the Yamamoto family. The family and I were able to exchange information and keep in contact after the fellowship ended. The area in which I stayed for the majority of the fellowship, in Hirono, was more of a rural area with few people who spoke English which required me to learn additional Japanese by immersion. Perhaps the biggest benefit was the opportunity I gained to promote fellowships like these to other students and most importantly to those who may not realize that a career in the sciences is attainable.
